Notes to Editors
t42 IoT Tracking Solutions plc
(AIM: TRAC), formerly Starcom Systems plc, provides real-time tracking, analysis, monitoring, and security IoT solutions for the global container and freight market and covers 55 countries, over 100 distributors, and 50 logistics and support partners.
t42's multi-sensor IoT tracking devices use a wide range of detection capabilities with cloud-based analytics and alerts, with real-time data transmission, analysis, and actionable insights. Its devices are used by ports, cargo owners, shipping companies, freight forwarders, insurance companies, customs authorities, homeland security, and police for end-to-end global container tracking and digital transformation of shipments.
The Annual Report will be made available to shareholders shortly and be available from the CompanyÕs website at:
www.t42.co.uk/
.
CHAIRMAN'S STATEMENT
We are pleased to report the audited results of t42 for the year ended 31 December 2022: revenues were $4.04m (2021: $ 4.21m), gross margin was 42% (2021: 40%), and net losses after tax were reduced to $1.01m (2021: $2.96m).
A major contributing factor to these results, as stated in our trading update in February 2023, is the continuation of post-Covid and supply chain issues that have impacted our performance despite several successful trials of our technology by potential customers. We also experienced delays in the anticipated substantial orders from our LATAM distributor caused by local political disturbances but are hopeful that we will begin to see progress in the level of demand in the latter part of this year.
Looking forward to the remainder of 2023, we are targeting a significant improvement in revenues and gross margins. This optimism is based on several business vectors and improvements, which we initially highlighted last year. First,
we have expanded in the USA with initial orders for Tetis units based on monthly payments for both devices and our software solutions. We see significant business potential in offering this innovative method to our product solutions and, assuming the required funding is available, we expect to deliver increased revenues by offering this payment solution in the USA and elsewhere.
Secondly, we have completed major software and hardware improvements to meet clientsÕ needs and provide more holistic solutions, particularly in times of a global chip shortage. We have been working hard to make our products even better, faster, and more reliable. We are confident these improvements will make a real difference and help us stay ahead of the competition.
We have upgraded our entire product range to incorporate support for LTE Cat-1 (which has much better world-wide 4G coverage than previous devices with Cat-M1), as older generations of cellular networks are being phased out worldwide. We have moved our cloud infrastructure to Amazon Web Services (AWS), which will improve the operational capability of our products. Furthermore, we have added new features to our products, for example, new types of reports, dashboards, and improvements to our control center, and enhanced the security feature across our product range. These improvements are expected to reduce manufacturing costs, thus improving our gross margins.
Thirdly, in 2022, we introduced four new products to the market: Tetis R Connect (Tetis R with BLE 4.2 support for scanning external standalone sensors for temperature, humidity, etc.), the Lokies 2.0 (featuring a new design, BLE 5.2 support, a new CPU, and improved energy efficiency), the new iteration of our Helios TT device, and two new versions of Helios M (for 2G and 4G networks).
Finally, we have significantly expanded our presence at specialized exhibitions related to our technology while implementing multiple pilot schemes with new and existing customers. This has provided the opportunity to engage in pilot tests for our latest Lokies and Tetis products and receive valuable customer feedback.
We are already beginning to see the positive result of these im

data.title: Strategic partnership with Israel’s largest port
data.full_content:
4 May 2023 15:45
RNS Number : 4769Y
T42 IOT Tracking Solutions PLC
04 May 2023
4 May 2023
t42 IoT Tracking Solutions plc
("t42" or the "Company")
New strategic partnership with Israel's largest port
t42 IoT Tracking Solutions plc (AIM: TRAC) ("
t42
" or the "
Company
") is pleased to announce that it has been selected from hundreds of companies offering innovative initiatives to provide its technology and to work in partnership with Ashdod Port (the "Port"), Israel's busiest container gateways (the "Partnership").
The "Innovation at Ashdod Port" program aims to improve global supply chains. The Port's management reviewed hundreds of companies and selected t42 to work in partnership with, as well as agreeing to promote the Company's tracking solutions. The Partnership will promote the Company's solutions and services, with the aim of improving demand and value proposition.
The Port will actively promote t42 products among its worldwide partners within both maritime and shipping container markets, including global cargo and shipment companies, providing an opportunity to enhance their collaboration and synchronization processes by utilizing the tracking solutions offered by t42. This promotion and the Partnership thus creates a potential business opportunity for the Company.
As part of this initiative, the Port will execute a pilot program with the Company to enhance internal activities and processes for greater efficiency by installing t42 operated units at the Port's service zones and containers, to track and forecast supply movements accurately.
Avi Hartmann, CEO of t42, commented
:
"
Our technology has been selected for the Ashdod Port innovation program, demonstrating confidence in the ability of our solutions to save time and money at one of Israel's largest ports. We expect the new strategic partnership to increase awareness of our supply chain solutions among major global cargo companies, and we look forward to signing new contracts following this partnership
."

data.title: Year-End Trading Update
data.full_content:
16 Feb 2023 07:00
RNS Number : 0660Q
T42 IOT Tracking Solutions PLC
16 February 2023
16 February 2023
t42 IoT Tracking Solutions plc
("t42" or the "Company")
T42 year-end trading update
t42
IoT Tracking Solutions plc (AIM: TRAC) ("
t42
" or the "
Company
"), the provider of global shipping containers tracking solutions, is pleased to provide the following trading update for the year ended 31 December 2022 (
"FY2022"
) and an update on the Company's prospects for the current year. The Company expects to announce its audited results for the year ended 31 December 2022 in March 2023.
The Company expects to report total revenues for FY2022 of approximately US$4.0 million, including approximately $2.0 million
o
f SaaS income representing approximately 50% of the total revenues for the period (2021:
51
%). This result was achieved in spite of the global supply chain issues faced by many companies and continuing business recovery from the Covid pandemic.
In 2022, the Company continued its expansion and is now well-positioned for this year with numerous opportunities and potential new key customers. It has continued its ongoing transition into the shipping container business sector with a number of pilot studies with potential new customers. As a result, initial orders from clients in the USA, South America, and Israel have been received, indicating a positive outlook for 2023.
This year started with presentations of
the Company's innovative solutions through DHL, Eseye, and other partners at key exhibitions in Brazil and Barcelona. The growing awareness of t42's Lokies and other products is already generating new leads and business opportunities.
Furthermore, the Company expects to extend its presence in South America following the deals announced last year. Although small initial orders were received in 2022 due to local political reasons, t42's distributor expects that the situation will improve in the first half of this year
and that more substantial orders will begin to be received
.
Following the growing demand in Africa,
the Company continues to support its Helios product line, meeting the need for product development. This includes integration support for 2G networks and above and tailor-designed solutions for various sectors, including t42's tracking and securing solutions for sensitive medical store deliveries supporting its long-term Tanzanian customers' requirements. Elsewhere,
the relationship with Zero motorcycles continues to be very positive, and further orders are expected this year.
The Company also announced the appointment of Openbox as a new distributor in the USA. Whilst so far they have not performed according to their expectations, nevertheless T42 has succeeded in directly winning new business in the USA, as announced in January 2023. Further orders are expected to be received during the course of 2023.
In recent months t42 has made several enhancements to its product offering through a new business model, which has been well-received by both existing and new potential customers. A significant development was the Company's decision to offer services while structuring payments for both devices and SaaS fees on a monthly payment basis as a leasing contract. t42 has already successfully contracted with a major USA company, adopting this payment structure, and who has indicated its intention to place further orders during 2023. The Company expects this structure to attract new clients and is evaluating funding requirements to support expansion of this new business model.
The Company is targeting significant revenue improvement in 2023 based on continued business with existing clients, including ongoing SaaS revenues. Meanwhile, the Company is focusing on the need to accelerate upfront cash payments to suppliers to shorten the supply chain period and ensure delivery preference. In parallel, the Board continues to explore acquisition opportunities to further broaden its business base and
strengthen its presence in its key markets.
Avi Hartmann, CEO of t42, commented
: "We move forward with the new potential customers while implementing the lessons learned from the completed pilots and existing business. Our new strategy focusing on shipping container businesses has proven itself, with increasing demand for our products and services. With the new offering of lease-based contracts, the t42 Board is looking forward to the coming year with confidence."

The agreement provides for monthly payments over a 36 month period to cover both device and data costs.
The client is a US-based company, one of the leading global companies that provide a unified view of in-transit logistics to detect and correct non-compliance within supply chains. Using the Tetis units as part of its solutions, the client is able to provide its customers with a much higher level of visibility and control over their cargo performance. The client's adoption of the Tetis highlights the need for the Company's technology in this growing segment. The client indicated that additional orders of Tetis units would likely be placed in the near future.
Avi Hartmann, CEO of t42, commented
: "The promising start to 2023 continues through this order and demonstrates trust in our products and services. As part of the partnership, we look forward to working with this client in order to provide better visibility and control for supply chains globally and hope to receive further orders under the agreement in the coming months."

data.title: T42 signs important agreement for Lokies units
data.full_content:
16 Jan 2023 07:30
RNS Number : 8042M
T42 IOT Tracking Solutions PLC
16 January 2023
16 January 202
3
t42 IoT Tracking Solutions plc
("t42", the "Company" or the "Group")
T42 signs important agreement for container shipping Lokies tracking units
t42
IoT Tracking Solutions plc (AIM: TRAC) ("
t42
" or the "
Company
"), the provider of global shipping containers tracking solutions, is pleased to announce that, through its wholly-owned subsidiary T42 Limited, the Group has entered into an agreement with a new Israel-based customer that provides cutting-edge IoT and AI solutions for monitoring goods in the supply chain ("
the Customer
") for the sale of t42's Lokies tracking units to protect goods and deliveries worldwide.
The agreement is for a two-year term. An initial purchase order has been received from the Customer for 1,500 Lokies units in respect of H1 2023 sales, with further orders anticipated over the period of the contract (including recurring revenue streams over the following years). The Customer has been granted certain end-client supply exclusivity rights, subject to the Customer achieving specified quarterly sales over a 2-year period for, in aggregate, 5,000 Lokies, including the units ordered to date.
Lokies is a unique smart keyless padlock with innovative IoT capabilities, incorporating advanced GPS and cellular technology together with new Bluetooth Low Energy connectivity and user management abilities. Lokies enables customers to identify and manage different users based on their access authorizations, making the cargo much more visible and secure.
The Customer is a leading provider of end-to-end services for goods management. Using AI models, it provides shipment data and business intelligence services, allowing for effective management of supply chains.
Avi Hartmann, CEO of t42, commented:
"
We recognize the growing demand for supply chain management solutions and the great potential of this multibillion-dollar industry. This new agreement puts our IoT solutions in the spotlight, and endorses the confidence the industry has in our technology."

data.title: Financial Update
data.full_content:
15 Dec 2022 13:30
RNS Number : 8797J
T42 IOT Tracking Solutions PLC
15 December 2022
15 December 2022
t42 IoT Tracking Solutions plc
("t42" or the "Company")
T42 Financial Update
t42
IoT Tracking Solutions plc (AIM: TRAC) ("
t42
" or the "
Company
"), the provider of global shipping container tracking solutions, announces that it has raised c. US$611k (gross) through a combination of debt and equity subscriptions, and arranged settlement of a further c. US$328k of supplier debt through a convertible loan, as detailed further below. The new funding will be used to strengthen the Company's balance sheet as well as to support its future growth.
Debt Facility
The Company has, through its wholly-owned subsidiary T42 Limited, entered into a loan agreement ("Agreement") with CSS A
lpha
Global Pte Ltd ("CSS") for the provision of a 12-month secured US$500,000 debt facility ("Facility"), to support manufacturing commitments and working capital needs. The Agreement provides, inter alia, for interest at 2 per cent per month, with 9 monthly repayments starting 3 months after drawdown. Security is by way of a second charge on assets, a personal, guarantee from Avi Hartman, CEO, limited to 20 per cent of the loan and a deposit with CSS of 3,000,000 new t42 shares ("Deposit Shares"). In addition, warrants for a total of 2,976,185 shares in t42 have been issued to CSS, exercisable at 7p per share over 5 years. The Facility includes representations and warranties by the Company that are customary for an agreement of this nature. The Agreement is subject to Mr Hartman not resigning as CEO of T42 Limited during the term of the Facility.
There is no penalty for prepaying the Agreement at any time.
Convertible Loan
The Company has issued a £265,000 convertible loan note ("CLN") to a supplier, to be applied in lieu of settlement of a supplier debt, assisting with the Company's cashflow management. The CLN bears interest at 3% per annum, payable quarterly, and is repayable by 31 December 2024. The CLN is convertible at 9p per share at the discretion of the holder. In addition, he Company has the right to enforce conversion of £100,000 of the CLN in the event t42's share price exceeds 12p and the balance if the share price exceeds 15p.
Equity Subscription
The Company has raised £90,000 through the subscription by 12.64 Fund, a fund managed by A-LABS Finance & Advisory Ltd, for 1,000,000 new Shares at 9p per share, representing a market premium of over 40% as of the last market close.
Admission
The new Shares will rank pari passu with the Company's existing ordinary shares, and application will be made to the London Stock Exchange plc for the admission of the 4,000,000 new Shares to trading on AIM. It is expected that such admission will be effective and dealings will commence on or around 21 December 2022.
Total Voting Rights
Following admission of the Deposit Shares and the Shares pursuant to the equity subscription there will be 57,026,822 Shares in issue, each with one voting right. The Company does not hold any Shares in treasury. This figure may be used by shareholders in the Company as the denominator for the calculations by which they will determine if they are required to notify their interest in, or a change to their interest in, the share capital of the Company under the FCA's Disclosure Guidance and Transparency Rules.
Avi Hartmann, CEO of t42, commented
:
"We are pleased to have secured this funding which will support the ongoing orders flow during this challenging era in the Global environment. Our pipeline remains strong though mainly expected to deliver sales during the first half of 2023 and beyond"
The information communicated in this announcement is deemed by the Company to constitute inside information for the purposes of Article 7 of as stipulated under the Market Abuse Regulation (EU) No. 596/2014 as it forms part of United Kingdom domestic law by virtue of the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018, as amended.

data.author: bunsenburner123
data.content: TRAC at £1.3m market cap – quick take •	Real business, not a story •	H1 revenue: $2.3m (≈£1.8m) •	Annualised ≈ £3.5–4m •	Positive EBITDA ($239k) •	Valuation is absurdly low •	Trading at ~0.35× sales •	Most AIM IoT names sit 1–2×+ sales •	Margins improving fast •	GM up to 48% •	Target 55% in H2 •	Margin expansion = sharp EBITDA leverage •	Growth engine working •	Lokies revenues up 200% YoY •	Shows product–market fit, not legacy decay •	Balance sheet risk reduced •	CLNs pushed to 2027 •	No near-term dilution pressure ⸻ What this implies •	Fundamentals alone justify £3–4m (2–3×) •	If growth + margins land: £5–6m (4×) •	Any container-tracking JV: £8–10m+ (6–8×) ⸻ Why it’s still cheap •	Illiquid •	Under-followed •	No big catalyst yet ⸻ Bottom line At £1.3m, TRAC looks mispriced: •	Downside relatively limited •	Upside asymmetric •	You’re getting the container-tracking option for free

data.author: Nig1954
data.content: I'm not aware that any specified chartist has issued a prediction about the performance of t42 in 2026 as I haven't seen any widely publicised forecast by a major financial analyst or firm. There's a lot of speculative discussions on share forums which suggests that the general sentiment is positive and that 2026 could shape up to be a strong year due to business improvements and new contracts and that it appears to be getting its finances in order. However, technical analysts really struggle to accurately predict share price movements in AIM companies due to the specific structural characteristics of AIM. Many companies have low trading volumes making it extremely difficult to buy or sell large positions without significantly affecting the the price. Low liquidity means that price movements are often erratic driven by a few large trades or individual investors rather than broad market psychology. There is often less media and analysis coverage which means information isn't widely disseminated or "priced in" efficiently which leads to sudden news driven price swings that no chart pattern could predict. Share prices of small companies are usually linked to single significant events such as a major contract win which happen without warning and can cause huge one-off price movements that defy historical patterns. Prices are also more susceptible to manipulation and the lack of sufficient reliable  historical data means its almost impossible impossible to form robust technical analysis which weighs heavily on past price action. Strong fundamentals are what drives the price of companies similar to t42 and these focus on the intrinsic value, financial health and management quality of the underlying company. Management have been making a lot of optimistic noises since the rebranding but nothing fundamental will change until they announce a major breakthrough with an award winning contract gain which will significantly improve the company's finances. t42 doesn't hold surplus cash so its scope is limited unless it can draw upon support from other financial benefactors but this will come at a price, possibly share dilution, or some of the financial rewards being diverted elsewhere. Their products seem to be held in high regard and they  proved their resilience during the recent AWS outage when many of their competitors struggled. I like the architectural design of their products and clearly a lot of thought and careful long term planning has gone into this which means they're less prone to suffering from unforeseen events which cripple many of their close competitors. For the moment they haven't managed to break through the ceiling despite all of the optimism generated several years ago with talks of multi-million dollars contracts in LatAm. The fact they've managed to survive for so long in such a cut throat environment  is some form of testament to their resilience but all of that optimism needs to be turned into something more tangible.

data.author: bunsenburner123
data.content: 🔥 TRAC is one of those rare AIM setups where the risk/reward is genuinely asymmetric. At a £1.5m market cap, you’re effectively buying a real, revenue-generating IoT business for less than the value of its tech, customer pipeline, and future optionality combined. This isn’t a concept stock anymore — it’s executing: •	Revenues growing fast •	EBITDA turning positive •	Costs under control •	Real customers, real hardware, real recurring income The kicker? The market is still pricing it like it’s broken. If even one of the following lands: •	a meaningful contract announcement •	a strategic partner or JV •	confirmation of sustained profitability •	or broader recognition of its container-tracking tech …the rerate could be violent. At £1.5m, this is the kind of setup where: •	2× feels reasonable •	3–5× is very possible •	and anything larger becomes plausible if momentum builds It’s exactly the sort of small-cap that quietly trades sideways… then suddenly reprices in days, not months. High risk? Yes. High conviction upside? Absolutely. This is the kind of stock that doesn’t reward hesitation — it rewards being early.

data.author: Nig1954
data.content: I couldn't make this years AGM but am told it was relatively upbeat despite very little being revealed. Apparently we're expecting improved Revenues and GP margins and may even turn EBITDA+ which would be extremely welcoming. Uri was pressed about our resilience following the AWS outage and whether our competitors could replicate what we did in order to remain operational. Uri maintains it would take 2/3 years for a competitor to replicate because that capability is engineered into our platform and isn't something that could be done overnight. This forms part of the technological advantage our products have which in Management's view would take a third party 2/3 years to catch-up but in the meantime we may have moved further ahead. Some parties thought it was suggested we may get an update in early February. I wouldn't bet on that but would be extremely pleased if this comes to fruition. So following the 2025 Interims, the headlines are revenue is growing, gross margins are improving, and adjusted EBITDA may have flipped positive. There is also a sizeable post-period contract that pays upfront – exactly what you want to see in a hardware-plus-SaaS business. Management says it is on track for at least 200% year-over-year growth in Lokies revenues. Hardware sales today plant the seeds for higher-margin software tomorrow, because each deployed device drives ongoing SaaS subscriptions and that change in mix is already visible with hopefully SaaS doing the heavy lifting on margins. Additional improvement in gross profit margins would be the tailwind towards profitability. The upfront payment on the Contguard contract is most welcome with some Revenue landing in 2025 and the majority in 2026 but that's excellent for cashflow and reduces execution risk. There are tighter protections for lenders and hitting those monthly payments is important. On the + side one of the loans is already being repaid in instalments. According to their cash flow forecasts Management believes that with the benefit of production efficiencies, customer purchase agreements and the loan extensions that  it can meet its obligations. However,  the two CLNs are convertible into up to 117.1 million shares as at 30 June 2025. That is a significant source of potential dilution if converted. In Ecuador,  integration has been completed and initial vehicles are connected. Management expects deployments to have increased in H2/25 whilst in Mexico,– roughly half of the contract has been executed, with the remainder currently on hold. No timeline disclosed. There are more products to broaden the addressable market and improve the SaaS opportunity whilst diversifying away from any single device line. Overall, the business is beginning to show signs of slowly moving in the right direction on sales, margins and profitability measures, albeit from a constrained balance sheet. If t42 converts its sales pipeline and keeps costs tight, the operational progress could start to outpace

data.author: LTbeliever
data.content: The MM is obliged to create a market in the shares of even illiquid stocks; the lower the volume, the bigger the spread needed to compensate (so, quite usual for small AIM stocks); in T42's case, the MM knows that next week's RNS may cause a big change in the SP (upwards, IMO), hence, on the one hand they need to keep hold of stock until volumes increase, on the other hand the public info available (re T42's rerate that should follow a good RNS) does not justify now a rise in the Bid SP; hence, the MM increases the Offer SP to keep the spread wide; of course, they could lower the Bid but that may expose them to a rush of BUYs without suffcient stock; all IMO; we will see next week when the SP jumps (IMO) and hopefully volumes too, thus reducing the spread. GLA, DYOR

data.author: bunsenburner123
data.content: TRAC at £1.3m market cap – quick take •	Real business, not a story •	H1 revenue: $2.3m (≈£1.8m) •	Annualised ≈ £3.5–4m •	Positive EBITDA ($239k) •	Valuation is absurdly low •	Trading at ~0.35× sales •	Most AIM IoT names sit 1–2×+ sales •	Margins improving fast •	GM up to 48% •	Target 55% in H2 •	Margin expansion = sharp EBITDA leverage •	Growth engine working •	Lokies revenues up 200% YoY •	Shows product–market fit, not legacy decay •	Balance sheet risk reduced •	CLNs pushed to 2027 •	No near-term dilution pressure ⸻ What this implies •	Fundamentals alone justify £3–4m (2–3×) •	If growth + margins land: £5–6m (4×) •	Any container-tracking JV: £8–10m+ (6–8×) ⸻ Why it’s still cheap •	Illiquid •	Under-followed •	No big catalyst yet ⸻ Bottom line At £1.3m, TRAC looks mispriced: •	Downside relatively limited •	Upside asymmetric •	You’re getting the container-tracking option for free

data.content: Knowledgeable poster, thanks for this summary 👍 Could you also please educate us regarding whatever has happened to their other (non logistics) related businesses, some of which imo seemed to previously have real potential for growth etc by the Company, e.g.: - crops monitoring - EV motorcycle engine monitoring - Heart defibrillators - other ? These various businesses just seemed to suddenly disappear from getting any further mention in RNS, Annual Reports, etc back a few years ago around the time of the Company name change (Starlink to T42 lot Track) when focus was towards logistics related business. Were these other businesses including their related IP aspects etc retained by TRAC (active/dormant), sold-off, disbanded at nil value, etc ? Hope you can help clarify as I could foresee under the radar hidden value for some of these businesses still exists within TRAC.

data.author: LTbeliever
data.content: After a horrid 2025, but with steady improvements, IMO 2026 is shaping up to be a great year for TRAC; irrespective of what could be announced (or more probably NOT) at the AGM in 2 days, the progress since August should feed through to the SP in H1 2026; we had 4mln REV in 2024, heading for 5mln in 2025 and a small Profit thanks to the August Contguard agreement, with more to come in 2026; looking at 7-8mln REV in 2026 (just adding the 2mln from Contg.), with higher margins as SaaS mix of sales increases Vs the lower margin Hardware; another positive signal is the 500-600k+ of the CLoan repayments (cap+int) due to be repaid in 2026 (implying IMO that the Co expects additional - to 2025 - Sales of at least 1.5mln, so the extra cashflow will go towards repayments). GLA, just a few weeks left to a March trading update re 2025.  And a Happy New year!

data.author: Nig1954
data.content: We'll see what the AGM brings along in 2 days time. Personally I'm looking for some clarity and realism as it's been deafeningly quiet this year with no discernible indication of anymore contract wins other than Contguard. An up-to-date assessment of the contracts announced in 2023 and 2024 would be most welcome. I'm hoping that H2/25 performance will reflect that when the Y/E accounting position is revealed. An update would also be welcome in relation to the development of our revolutionary innovative new product solution for the refrigerated air cargo supply chain. Hopefully this will represent a paradigm shift for the air cargo industry providing unprecedented control, efficiency and profitability, as previously promised. Two and a half years and still waiting on that score. There were also those series of mysterious tweets back in April/ May 2025 which supposedly signalled some imminent good news which doesn't yet appear to have materialised. An indication of the progress would be appreciated. Finally  resilience of t42's products was proven in the recent AWS outage which apparently made the Industry sit up and take note. Are there any signs that this will translate into larger and more profitable contracts for the company.

data.author: Nig1954
data.content: I'm not aware that any specified chartist has issued a prediction about the performance of t42 in 2026 as I haven't seen any widely publicised forecast by a major financial analyst or firm. There's a lot of speculative discussions on share forums which suggests that the general sentiment is positive and that 2026 could shape up to be a strong year due to business improvements and new contracts and that it appears to be getting its finances in order. However, technical analysts really struggle to accurately predict share price movements in AIM companies due to the specific structural characteristics of AIM. Many companies have low trading volumes making it extremely difficult to buy or sell large positions without significantly affecting the the price. Low liquidity means that price movements are often erratic driven by a few large trades or individual investors rather than broad market psychology. There is often less media and analysis coverage which means information isn't widely disseminated or "priced in" efficiently which leads to sudden news driven price swings that no chart pattern could predict. Share prices of small companies are usually linked to single significant events such as a major contract win which happen without warning and can cause huge one-off price movements that defy historical patterns. Prices are also more susceptible to manipulation and the lack of sufficient reliable  historical data means its almost impossible impossible to form robust technical analysis which weighs heavily on past price action. Strong fundamentals are what drives the price of companies similar to t42 and these focus on the intrinsic value, financial health and management quality of the underlying company. Management have been making a lot of optimistic noises since the rebranding but nothing fundamental will change until they announce a major breakthrough with an award winning contract gain which will significantly improve the company's finances. t42 doesn't hold surplus cash so its scope is limited unless it can draw upon support from other financial benefactors but this will come at a price, possibly share dilution, or some of the financial rewards being diverted elsewhere. Their products seem to be held in high regard and they  proved their resilience during the recent AWS outage when many of their competitors struggled. I like the architectural design of their products and clearly a lot of thought and careful long term planning has gone into this which means they're less prone to suffering from unforeseen events which cripple many of their close competitors. For the moment they haven't managed to break through the ceiling despite all of the optimism generated several years ago with talks of multi-million dollars contracts in LatAm. The fact they've managed to survive for so long in such a cut throat environment  is some form of testament to their resilience but all of that optimism needs to be turned into something more tangible.

data.author: bunsenburner123
data.content: 🔥 TRAC is one of those rare AIM setups where the risk/reward is genuinely asymmetric. At a £1.5m market cap, you’re effectively buying a real, revenue-generating IoT business for less than the value of its tech, customer pipeline, and future optionality combined. This isn’t a concept stock anymore — it’s executing: •	Revenues growing fast •	EBITDA turning positive •	Costs under control •	Real customers, real hardware, real recurring income The kicker? The market is still pricing it like it’s broken. If even one of the following lands: •	a meaningful contract announcement •	a strategic partner or JV •	confirmation of sustained profitability •	or broader recognition of its container-tracking tech …the rerate could be violent. At £1.5m, this is the kind of setup where: •	2× feels reasonable •	3–5× is very possible •	and anything larger becomes plausible if momentum builds It’s exactly the sort of small-cap that quietly trades sideways… then suddenly reprices in days, not months. High risk? Yes. High conviction upside? Absolutely. This is the kind of stock that doesn’t reward hesitation — it rewards being early.

data.author: LTbeliever
data.content: @Nig1954 , Thanks for your post, I agree with it except this comment "t42 doesn't hold surplus cash so its scope is limited..."; Co raised cash in 2023 (1mln+ in GBP), took 2 years to burn through, then raised again almost 1 year ago (262k) - IMO, this indicates that cash burn has dwindled, 2023-2024 were the difficult transition years and as Aug 2025 RNSs showed, the cash situation is now stable and improving, given that: 1. Both CLoans extended to eo2027; 2. One is being repaid in full by then, in payments of 25-75k per month (as per Notes in last Interims), showing repayment capacity, hence positive cash flow; 3. Contguard paying the Co in advance of orders, hence a CFlow of 2.5mln between Sept2025-Dec2026 - IMO, this is the game changer re Cash Flow requirements (i.e. surplus); All the Market needs now is the 2025 Trading Update, to show - IMO - a Net Profit and positive CFlow.  DYOR & GLA!

The situation pertaining to Contguard is different because it is a member of the Ewave Group. Having said that it shouldn't be too difficult to raise the necessary funds on reasonable pricing terms if it's a guaranteed order which has stipulated delivery terms.

data.content: Thanks Nig1954; IMO, connection to Ewave Group (1000 employees), owned by publicly listed Comp. Direct Group ($500mln cap) is a plus for T42 ; https://pitchbook.com/profiles/company/165527-20#overview It may be a 3rd party but it's a debtor, client and reliant on T42's tech/services so it has a vested interest in T42 doing well enough to keep growing and repaying its debt. The August RNS also stated that "The order reflects only part of the growth in demand expected from Contguard, whose operational performance has led to a marked increase in order volumes", implying more orders in 2026 and beyond, IMO.

data.author: Nig1954
data.content: I couldn't make this years AGM but am told it was relatively upbeat despite very little being revealed. Apparently we're expecting improved Revenues and GP margins and may even turn EBITDA+ which would be extremely welcoming. Uri was pressed about our resilience following the AWS outage and whether our competitors could replicate what we did in order to remain operational. Uri maintains it would take 2/3 years for a competitor to replicate because that capability is engineered into our platform and isn't something that could be done overnight. This forms part of the technological advantage our products have which in Management's view would take a third party 2/3 years to catch-up but in the meantime we may have moved further ahead. Some parties thought it was suggested we may get an update in early February. I wouldn't bet on that but would be extremely pleased if this comes to fruition. So following the 2025 Interims, the headlines are revenue is growing, gross margins are improving, and adjusted EBITDA may have flipped positive. There is also a sizeable post-period contract that pays upfront – exactly what you want to see in a hardware-plus-SaaS business. Management says it is on track for at least 200% year-over-year growth in Lokies revenues. Hardware sales today plant the seeds for higher-margin software tomorrow, because each deployed device drives ongoing SaaS subscriptions and that change in mix is already visible with hopefully SaaS doing the heavy lifting on margins. Additional improvement in gross profit margins would be the tailwind towards profitability. The upfront payment on the Contguard contract is most welcome with some Revenue landing in 2025 and the majority in 2026 but that's excellent for cashflow and reduces execution risk. There are tighter protections for lenders and hitting those monthly payments is important. On the + side one of the loans is already being repaid in instalments. According to their cash flow forecasts Management believes that with the benefit of production efficiencies, customer purchase agreements and the loan extensions that  it can meet its obligations. However,  the two CLNs are convertible into up to 117.1 million shares as at 30 June 2025. That is a significant source of potential dilution if converted. In Ecuador,  integration has been completed and initial vehicles are connected. Management expects deployments to have increased in H2/25 whilst in Mexico,– roughly half of the contract has been executed, with the remainder currently on hold. No timeline disclosed. There are more products to broaden the addressable market and improve the SaaS opportunity whilst diversifying away from any single device line. Overall, the business is beginning to show signs of slowly moving in the right direction on sales, margins and profitability measures, albeit from a constrained balance sheet. If t42 converts its sales pipeline and keeps costs tight, the operational progress could start to outpace

Hardware sales today plant the seeds for higher-margin software tomorrow, because each deployed device drives ongoing SaaS subscriptions and that change in mix is already visible with hopefully SaaS doing the heavy lifting on margins. Additional improvement in gross profit margins would be the tailwind towards profitability. The upfront payment on the Contguard contract is most welcome with some Revenue landing in 2025 and the majority in 2026 but that's excellent for cashflow and reduces execution risk. There are tighter protections for lenders and hitting those monthly payments is important. On the + side one of the loans is already being repaid in instalments. According to their cash flow forecasts Management believes that with the benefit of production efficiencies, customer purchase agreements and the loan extensions that  it can meet its obligations. However,  the two CLNs are convertible into up to 117.1 million shares as at 30 June 2025. That is a significant source of potential dilution if converted. In Ecuador,  integration has been completed and initial vehicles are connected. Management expects deployments to have increased in H2/25 whilst in Mexico,– roughly half of the contract has been executed, with the remainder currently on hold. No timeline disclosed. There are more products to broaden the addressable market and improve the SaaS opportunity whilst diversifying away from any single device line. Overall, the business is beginning to show signs of slowly moving in the right direction on sales, margins and profitability measures, albeit from a constrained balance sheet. If t42 converts its sales pipeline and keeps costs tight, the operational progress could start to outpace

data.author: LTbeliever
data.content: The MM is obliged to create a market in the shares of even illiquid stocks; the lower the volume, the bigger the spread needed to compensate (so, quite usual for small AIM stocks); in T42's case, the MM knows that next week's RNS may cause a big change in the SP (upwards, IMO), hence, on the one hand they need to keep hold of stock until volumes increase, on the other hand the public info available (re T42's rerate that should follow a good RNS) does not justify now a rise in the Bid SP; hence, the MM increases the Offer SP to keep the spread wide; of course, they could lower the Bid but that may expose them to a rush of BUYs without suffcient stock; all IMO; we will see next week when the SP jumps (IMO) and hopefully volumes too, thus reducing the spread. data.content: I couldn't make this years AGM but am told it was relatively upbeat despite very little being revealed. Uri maintains it would take 2/3 years for a competitor to replicate because that capability is engineered into our platform and isn't something that could be done overnight. This forms part of the technological advantage our products have which in Management's view would take a third party 2/3 years to catch-up but in the meantime we may have moved further ahead. Some parties thought it was suggested we may get an update in early February. I wouldn't bet on that but would be extremely pleased if this comes to fruition. So following the 2025 Interims, the headlines are revenue is growing, gross margins are improving, and adjusted EBITDA may have flipped positive. There is also a sizeable post-period contract that pays upfront – exactly what you want to see in a hardware-plus-SaaS business. Additional improvement in gross profit margins would be the tailwind towards profitability. The upfront payment on the Contguard contract is most welcome with some Revenue landing in 2025 and the majority in 2026 but that's excellent for cashflow and reduces execution risk. There are tighter protections for lenders and hitting those monthly payments is important. On the + side one of the loans is already being repaid in instalments. According to their cash flow forecasts Management believes that with the benefit of production efficiencies, customer purchase agreements and the loan extensions that  it can meet its obligations. However,  the two CLNs are convertible into up to 117.1 million shares as at 30 June 2025. That is a significant source of potential dilution if converted. In Ecuador,  integration has been completed and initial vehicles are connected. There are more products to broaden the addressable market and improve the SaaS opportunity whilst diversifying away from any single device line. Overall, the business is beginning to show signs of slowly moving in the right direction on sales, margins and profitability measures, albeit from a constrained balance sheet. data.author: LTbeliever
data.content: @Nig1954 , Thanks for your post, I agree with it except this comment "t42 doesn't hold surplus cash so its scope is limited..."; Co raised cash in 2023 (1mln+ in GBP), took 2 years to burn through, then raised again almost 1 year ago (262k) - IMO, this indicates that cash burn has dwindled, 2023-2024 were the difficult transition years and as Aug 2025 RNSs showed, the cash situation is now stable and improving, given that: 1. Both CLoans extended to eo2027; 2. One is being repaid in full by then, in payments of 25-75k per month (as per Notes in last Interims), showing repayment capacity, hence positive cash flow; 3. Contguard paying the Co in advance of orders, hence a CFlow of 2.5mln between Sept2025-Dec2026 - IMO, this is the game changer re Cash Flow requirements (i.e. surplus); All the Market needs now is the 2025 Trading Update, to show - IMO - a Net Profit and positive CFlow.  DYOR & GLA!

data.author: bunsenburner123
data.content: 🔥 TRAC is one of those rare AIM setups where the risk/reward is genuinely asymmetric. At a £1.5m market cap, you’re effectively buying a real, revenue-generating IoT business for less than the value of its tech, customer pipeline, and future optionality combined. This isn’t a concept stock anymore — it’s executing: •	Revenues growing fast •	EBITDA turning positive •	Costs under control •	Real customers, real hardware, real recurring income The kicker? The market is still pricing it like it’s broken. If even one of the following lands: •	a meaningful contract announcement •	a strategic partner or JV •	confirmation of sustained profitability •	or broader recognition of its container-tracking tech …the rerate could be violent. At £1.5m, this is the kind of setup where: •	2× feels reasonable •	3–5× is very possible •	and anything larger becomes plausible if momentum builds It’s exactly the sort of small-cap that quietly trades sideways… then suddenly reprices in days, not months. High risk? Yes. High conviction upside? Absolutely. This is the kind of stock that doesn’t reward hesitation — it rewards being early.

data.author: Nig1954
data.content: I'm not aware that any specified chartist has issued a prediction about the performance of t42 in 2026 as I haven't seen any widely publicised forecast by a major financial analyst or firm. There's a lot of speculative discussions on share forums which suggests that the general sentiment is positive and that 2026 could shape up to be a strong year due to business improvements and new contracts and that it appears to be getting its finances in order. However, technical analysts really struggle to accurately predict share price movements in AIM companies due to the specific structural characteristics of AIM. Many companies have low trading volumes making it extremely difficult to buy or sell large positions without significantly affecting the the price. Low liquidity means that price movements are often erratic driven by a few large trades or individual investors rather than broad market psychology. There is often less media and analysis coverage which means information isn't widely disseminated or "priced in" efficiently which leads to sudden news driven price swings that no chart pattern could predict. Share prices of small companies are usually linked to single significant events such as a major contract win which happen without warning and can cause huge one-off price movements that defy historical patterns. Prices are also more susceptible to manipulation and the lack of sufficient reliable  historical data means its almost impossible impossible to form robust technical analysis which weighs heavily on past price action. Strong fundamentals are what drives the price of companies similar to t42 and these focus on the intrinsic value, financial health and management quality of the underlying company. Management have been making a lot of optimistic noises since the rebranding but nothing fundamental will change until they announce a major breakthrough with an award winning contract gain which will significantly improve the company's finances. t42 doesn't hold surplus cash so its scope is limited unless it can draw upon support from other financial benefactors but this will come at a price, possibly share dilution, or some of the financial rewards being diverted elsewhere. Their products seem to be held in high regard and they  proved their resilience during the recent AWS outage when many of their competitors struggled. I like the architectural design of their products and clearly a lot of thought and careful long term planning has gone into this which means they're less prone to suffering from unforeseen events which cripple many of their close competitors. For the moment they haven't managed to break through the ceiling despite all of the optimism generated several years ago with talks of multi-million dollars contracts in LatAm. The fact they've managed to survive for so long in such a cut throat environment  is some form of testament to their resilience but all of that optimism needs to be turned into something more tangible.

data.author: Nig1954
data.content: I couldn't make this years AGM but am told it was relatively upbeat despite very little being revealed. Apparently we're expecting improved Revenues and GP margins and may even turn EBITDA+ which would be extremely welcoming. Uri was pressed about our resilience following the AWS outage and whether our competitors could replicate what we did in order to remain operational. Uri maintains it would take 2/3 years for a competitor to replicate because that capability is engineered into our platform and isn't something that could be done overnight. This forms part of the technological advantage our products have which in Management's view would take a third party 2/3 years to catch-up but in the meantime we may have moved further ahead. Some parties thought it was suggested we may get an update in early February. I wouldn't bet on that but would be extremely pleased if this comes to fruition. So following the 2025 Interims, the headlines are revenue is growing, gross margins are improving, and adjusted EBITDA may have flipped positive. There is also a sizeable post-period contract that pays upfront – exactly what you want to see in a hardware-plus-SaaS business. Management says it is on track for at least 200% year-over-year growth in Lokies revenues. Hardware sales today plant the seeds for higher-margin software tomorrow, because each deployed device drives ongoing SaaS subscriptions and that change in mix is already visible with hopefully SaaS doing the heavy lifting on margins. Additional improvement in gross profit margins would be the tailwind towards profitability. The upfront payment on the Contguard contract is most welcome with some Revenue landing in 2025 and the majority in 2026 but that's excellent for cashflow and reduces execution risk. There are tighter protections for lenders and hitting those monthly payments is important. On the + side one of the loans is already being repaid in instalments. According to their cash flow forecasts Management believes that with the benefit of production efficiencies, customer purchase agreements and the loan extensions that  it can meet its obligations. However,  the two CLNs are convertible into up to 117.1 million shares as at 30 June 2025. That is a significant source of potential dilution if converted. In Ecuador,  integration has been completed and initial vehicles are connected. Management expects deployments to have increased in H2/25 whilst in Mexico,– roughly half of the contract has been executed, with the remainder currently on hold. No timeline disclosed. There are more products to broaden the addressable market and improve the SaaS opportunity whilst diversifying away from any single device line. Overall, the business is beginning to show signs of slowly moving in the right direction on sales, margins and profitability measures, albeit from a constrained balance sheet. If t42 converts its sales pipeline and keeps costs tight, the operational progress could start to outpace

data.author: Nig1954
data.content: I couldn't make this years AGM but am told it was relatively upbeat despite very little being revealed. Apparently we're expecting improved Revenues and GP margins and may even turn EBITDA+ which would be extremely welcoming. Uri was pressed about our resilience following the AWS outage and whether our competitors could replicate what we did in order to remain operational. Uri maintains it would take 2/3 years for a competitor to replicate because that capability is engineered into our platform and isn't something that could be done overnight. This forms part of the technological advantage our products have which in Management's view would take a third party 2/3 years to catch-up but in the meantime we may have moved further ahead. Some parties thought it was suggested we may get an update in early February. I wouldn't bet on that but would be extremely pleased if this comes to fruition. So following the 2025 Interims, the headlines are revenue is growing, gross margins are improving, and adjusted EBITDA may have flipped positive. There is also a sizeable post-period contract that pays upfront – exactly what you want to see in a hardware-plus-SaaS business. Management says it is on track for at least 200% year-over-year growth in Lokies revenues. Hardware sales today plant the seeds for higher-margin software tomorrow, because each deployed device drives ongoing SaaS subscriptions and that change in mix is already visible with hopefully SaaS doing the heavy lifting on margins. Additional improvement in gross profit margins would be the tailwind towards profitability. The upfront payment on the Contguard contract is most welcome with some Revenue landing in 2025 and the majority in 2026 but that's excellent for cashflow and reduces execution risk. There are tighter protections for lenders and hitting those monthly payments is important. On the + side one of the loans is already being repaid in instalments. According to their cash flow forecasts Management believes that with the benefit of production efficiencies, customer purchase agreements and the loan extensions that  it can meet its obligations. However,  the two CLNs are convertible into up to 117.1 million shares as at 30 June 2025. That is a significant source of potential dilution if converted. In Ecuador,  integration has been completed and initial vehicles are connected. Management expects deployments to have increased in H2/25 whilst in Mexico,– roughly half of the contract has been executed, with the remainder currently on hold. No timeline disclosed. There are more products to broaden the addressable market and improve the SaaS opportunity whilst diversifying away from any single device line. Overall, the business is beginning to show signs of slowly moving in the right direction on sales, margins and profitability measures, albeit from a constrained balance sheet. If t42 converts its sales pipeline and keeps costs tight, the operational progress could start to outpace

data.author: bunsenburner123
data.content: 🔥 TRAC is one of those rare AIM setups where the risk/reward is genuinely asymmetric. At a £1.5m market cap, you’re effectively buying a real, revenue-generating IoT business for less than the value of its tech, customer pipeline, and future optionality combined. This isn’t a concept stock anymore — it’s executing: •	Revenues growing fast •	EBITDA turning positive •	Costs under control •	Real customers, real hardware, real recurring income The kicker? The market is still pricing it like it’s broken. If even one of the following lands: •	a meaningful contract announcement •	a strategic partner or JV •	confirmation of sustained profitability •	or broader recognition of its container-tracking tech …the rerate could be violent. At £1.5m, this is the kind of setup where: •	2× feels reasonable •	3–5× is very possible •	and anything larger becomes plausible if momentum builds It’s exactly the sort of small-cap that quietly trades sideways… then suddenly reprices in days, not months. High risk? Yes. High conviction upside? Absolutely. This is the kind of stock that doesn’t reward hesitation — it rewards being early.

data.author: Nig1954
data.content: I'm not aware that any specified chartist has issued a prediction about the performance of t42 in 2026 as I haven't seen any widely publicised forecast by a major financial analyst or firm. There's a lot of speculative discussions on share forums which suggests that the general sentiment is positive and that 2026 could shape up to be a strong year due to business improvements and new contracts and that it appears to be getting its finances in order. However, technical analysts really struggle to accurately predict share price movements in AIM companies due to the specific structural characteristics of AIM. Many companies have low trading volumes making it extremely difficult to buy or sell large positions without significantly affecting the the price. Low liquidity means that price movements are often erratic driven by a few large trades or individual investors rather than broad market psychology. There is often less media and analysis coverage which means information isn't widely disseminated or "priced in" efficiently which leads to sudden news driven price swings that no chart pattern could predict. Share prices of small companies are usually linked to single significant events such as a major contract win which happen without warning and can cause huge one-off price movements that defy historical patterns. Prices are also more susceptible to manipulation and the lack of sufficient reliable  historical data means its almost impossible impossible to form robust technical analysis which weighs heavily on past price action. Strong fundamentals are what drives the price of companies similar to t42 and these focus on the intrinsic value, financial health and management quality of the underlying company. Management have been making a lot of optimistic noises since the rebranding but nothing fundamental will change until they announce a major breakthrough with an award winning contract gain which will significantly improve the company's finances. t42 doesn't hold surplus cash so its scope is limited unless it can draw upon support from other financial benefactors but this will come at a price, possibly share dilution, or some of the financial rewards being diverted elsewhere. Their products seem to be held in high regard and they  proved their resilience during the recent AWS outage when many of their competitors struggled. I like the architectural design of their products and clearly a lot of thought and careful long term planning has gone into this which means they're less prone to suffering from unforeseen events which cripple many of their close competitors. For the moment they haven't managed to break through the ceiling despite all of the optimism generated several years ago with talks of multi-million dollars contracts in LatAm. The fact they've managed to survive for so long in such a cut throat environment  is some form of testament to their resilience but all of that optimism needs to be turned into something more tangible.

data.author: Nig1954
data.content: I couldn't make this years AGM but am told it was relatively upbeat despite very little being revealed. Apparently we're expecting improved Revenues and GP margins and may even turn EBITDA+ which would be extremely welcoming. Uri was pressed about our resilience following the AWS outage and whether our competitors could replicate what we did in order to remain operational. Uri maintains it would take 2/3 years for a competitor to replicate because that capability is engineered into our platform and isn't something that could be done overnight. This forms part of the technological advantage our products have which in Management's view would take a third party 2/3 years to catch-up but in the meantime we may have moved further ahead. Some parties thought it was suggested we may get an update in early February. I wouldn't bet on that but would be extremely pleased if this comes to fruition. So following the 2025 Interims, the headlines are revenue is growing, gross margins are improving, and adjusted EBITDA may have flipped positive. There is also a sizeable post-period contract that pays upfront – exactly what you want to see in a hardware-plus-SaaS business. Management says it is on track for at least 200% year-over-year growth in Lokies revenues. Hardware sales today plant the seeds for higher-margin software tomorrow, because each deployed device drives ongoing SaaS subscriptions and that change in mix is already visible with hopefully SaaS doing the heavy lifting on margins. Additional improvement in gross profit margins would be the tailwind towards profitability. The upfront payment on the Contguard contract is most welcome with some Revenue landing in 2025 and the majority in 2026 but that's excellent for cashflow and reduces execution risk. There are tighter protections for lenders and hitting those monthly payments is important. On the + side one of the loans is already being repaid in instalments. According to their cash flow forecasts Management believes that with the benefit of production efficiencies, customer purchase agreements and the loan extensions that  it can meet its obligations. However,  the two CLNs are convertible into up to 117.1 million shares as at 30 June 2025. That is a significant source of potential dilution if converted. In Ecuador,  integration has been completed and initial vehicles are connected. Management expects deployments to have increased in H2/25 whilst in Mexico,– roughly half of the contract has been executed, with the remainder currently on hold. No timeline disclosed. There are more products to broaden the addressable market and improve the SaaS opportunity whilst diversifying away from any single device line. Overall, the business is beginning to show signs of slowly moving in the right direction on sales, margins and profitability measures, albeit from a constrained balance sheet. If t42 converts its sales pipeline and keeps costs tight, the operational progress could start to outpace

data.author: bunsenburner123
data.content: 🔥 TRAC is one of those rare AIM setups where the risk/reward is genuinely asymmetric. At a £1.5m market cap, you’re effectively buying a real, revenue-generating IoT business for less than the value of its tech, customer pipeline, and future optionality combined. This isn’t a concept stock anymore — it’s executing: •	Revenues growing fast •	EBITDA turning positive •	Costs under control •	Real customers, real hardware, real recurring income The kicker? The market is still pricing it like it’s broken. If even one of the following lands: •	a meaningful contract announcement •	a strategic partner or JV •	confirmation of sustained profitability •	or broader recognition of its container-tracking tech …the rerate could be violent. At £1.5m, this is the kind of setup where: •	2× feels reasonable •	3–5× is very possible •	and anything larger becomes plausible if momentum builds It’s exactly the sort of small-cap that quietly trades sideways… then suddenly reprices in days, not months. High risk? Yes. High conviction upside? Absolutely. This is the kind of stock that doesn’t reward hesitation — it rewards being early.

data.author: Nig1954
data.content: I'm not aware that any specified chartist has issued a prediction about the performance of t42 in 2026 as I haven't seen any widely publicised forecast by a major financial analyst or firm. There's a lot of speculative discussions on share forums which suggests that the general sentiment is positive and that 2026 could shape up to be a strong year due to business improvements and new contracts and that it appears to be getting its finances in order. However, technical analysts really struggle to accurately predict share price movements in AIM companies due to the specific structural characteristics of AIM. Many companies have low trading volumes making it extremely difficult to buy or sell large positions without significantly affecting the the price. Low liquidity means that price movements are often erratic driven by a few large trades or individual investors rather than broad market psychology. There is often less media and analysis coverage which means information isn't widely disseminated or "priced in" efficiently which leads to sudden news driven price swings that no chart pattern could predict. Share prices of small companies are usually linked to single significant events such as a major contract win which happen without warning and can cause huge one-off price movements that defy historical patterns. Prices are also more susceptible to manipulation and the lack of sufficient reliable  historical data means its almost impossible impossible to form robust technical analysis which weighs heavily on past price action. Strong fundamentals are what drives the price of companies similar to t42 and these focus on the intrinsic value, financial health and management quality of the underlying company. Management have been making a lot of optimistic noises since the rebranding but nothing fundamental will change until they announce a major breakthrough with an award winning contract gain which will significantly improve the company's finances. t42 doesn't hold surplus cash so its scope is limited unless it can draw upon support from other financial benefactors but this will come at a price, possibly share dilution, or some of the financial rewards being diverted elsewhere. Their products seem to be held in high regard and they  proved their resilience during the recent AWS outage when many of their competitors struggled. I like the architectural design of their products and clearly a lot of thought and careful long term planning has gone into this which means they're less prone to suffering from unforeseen events which cripple many of their close competitors. For the moment they haven't managed to break through the ceiling despite all of the optimism generated several years ago with talks of multi-million dollars contracts in LatAm. The fact they've managed to survive for so long in such a cut throat environment  is some form of testament to their resilience but all of that optimism needs to be turned into something more tangible.

data.author: Nig1954
data.content: I couldn't make this years AGM but am told it was relatively upbeat despite very little being revealed. Apparently we're expecting improved Revenues and GP margins and may even turn EBITDA+ which would be extremely welcoming. Uri was pressed about our resilience following the AWS outage and whether our competitors could replicate what we did in order to remain operational. Uri maintains it would take 2/3 years for a competitor to replicate because that capability is engineered into our platform and isn't something that could be done overnight. This forms part of the technological advantage our products have which in Management's view would take a third party 2/3 years to catch-up but in the meantime we may have moved further ahead. Some parties thought it was suggested we may get an update in early February. I wouldn't bet on that but would be extremely pleased if this comes to fruition. So following the 2025 Interims, the headlines are revenue is growing, gross margins are improving, and adjusted EBITDA may have flipped positive. There is also a sizeable post-period contract that pays upfront – exactly what you want to see in a hardware-plus-SaaS business. Management says it is on track for at least 200% year-over-year growth in Lokies revenues. Hardware sales today plant the seeds for higher-margin software tomorrow, because each deployed device drives ongoing SaaS subscriptions and that change in mix is already visible with hopefully SaaS doing the heavy lifting on margins. Additional improvement in gross profit margins would be the tailwind towards profitability. The upfront payment on the Contguard contract is most welcome with some Revenue landing in 2025 and the majority in 2026 but that's excellent for cashflow and reduces execution risk. There are tighter protections for lenders and hitting those monthly payments is important. On the + side one of the loans is already being repaid in instalments. According to their cash flow forecasts Management believes that with the benefit of production efficiencies, customer purchase agreements and the loan extensions that  it can meet its obligations. However,  the two CLNs are convertible into up to 117.1 million shares as at 30 June 2025. That is a significant source of potential dilution if converted. In Ecuador,  integration has been completed and initial vehicles are connected. Management expects deployments to have increased in H2/25 whilst in Mexico,– roughly half of the contract has been executed, with the remainder currently on hold. No timeline disclosed. There are more products to broaden the addressable market and improve the SaaS opportunity whilst diversifying away from any single device line. Overall, the business is beginning to show signs of slowly moving in the right direction on sales, margins and profitability measures, albeit from a constrained balance sheet. If t42 converts its sales pipeline and keeps costs tight, the operational progress could start to outpace

data.author: bunsenburner123
data.content: 🔥 TRAC is one of those rare AIM setups where the risk/reward is genuinely asymmetric. At a £1.5m market cap, you’re effectively buying a real, revenue-generating IoT business for less than the value of its tech, customer pipeline, and future optionality combined. This isn’t a concept stock anymore — it’s executing: •	Revenues growing fast •	EBITDA turning positive •	Costs under control •	Real customers, real hardware, real recurring income The kicker? The market is still pricing it like it’s broken. If even one of the following lands: •	a meaningful contract announcement •	a strategic partner or JV •	confirmation of sustained profitability •	or broader recognition of its container-tracking tech …the rerate could be violent. At £1.5m, this is the kind of setup where: •	2× feels reasonable •	3–5× is very possible •	and anything larger becomes plausible if momentum builds It’s exactly the sort of small-cap that quietly trades sideways… then suddenly reprices in days, not months. High risk? Yes. High conviction upside? Absolutely. This is the kind of stock that doesn’t reward hesitation — it rewards being early.

data.author: Nig1954
data.content: I'm not aware that any specified chartist has issued a prediction about the performance of t42 in 2026 as I haven't seen any widely publicised forecast by a major financial analyst or firm. There's a lot of speculative discussions on share forums which suggests that the general sentiment is positive and that 2026 could shape up to be a strong year due to business improvements and new contracts and that it appears to be getting its finances in order. However, technical analysts really struggle to accurately predict share price movements in AIM companies due to the specific structural characteristics of AIM. Many companies have low trading volumes making it extremely difficult to buy or sell large positions without significantly affecting the the price. Low liquidity means that price movements are often erratic driven by a few large trades or individual investors rather than broad market psychology. There is often less media and analysis coverage which means information isn't widely disseminated or "priced in" efficiently which leads to sudden news driven price swings that no chart pattern could predict. Share prices of small companies are usually linked to single significant events such as a major contract win which happen without warning and can cause huge one-off price movements that defy historical patterns. Prices are also more susceptible to manipulation and the lack of sufficient reliable  historical data means its almost impossible impossible to form robust technical analysis which weighs heavily on past price action. Strong fundamentals are what drives the price of companies similar to t42 and these focus on the intrinsic value, financial health and management quality of the underlying company. Management have been making a lot of optimistic noises since the rebranding but nothing fundamental will change until they announce a major breakthrough with an award winning contract gain which will significantly improve the company's finances. t42 doesn't hold surplus cash so its scope is limited unless it can draw upon support from other financial benefactors but this will come at a price, possibly share dilution, or some of the financial rewards being diverted elsewhere. Their products seem to be held in high regard and they  proved their resilience during the recent AWS outage when many of their competitors struggled. I like the architectural design of their products and clearly a lot of thought and careful long term planning has gone into this which means they're less prone to suffering from unforeseen events which cripple many of their close competitors. For the moment they haven't managed to break through the ceiling despite all of the optimism generated several years ago with talks of multi-million dollars contracts in LatAm. The fact they've managed to survive for so long in such a cut throat environment  is some form of testament to their resilience but all of that optimism needs to be turned into something more tangible.

data.author: Nig1954
data.content: I couldn't make this years AGM but am told it was relatively upbeat despite very little being revealed. Apparently we're expecting improved Revenues and GP margins and may even turn EBITDA+ which would be extremely welcoming. Uri was pressed about our resilience following the AWS outage and whether our competitors could replicate what we did in order to remain operational. Uri maintains it would take 2/3 years for a competitor to replicate because that capability is engineered into our platform and isn't something that could be done overnight. This forms part of the technological advantage our products have which in Management's view would take a third party 2/3 years to catch-up but in the meantime we may have moved further ahead. Some parties thought it was suggested we may get an update in early February. I wouldn't bet on that but would be extremely pleased if this comes to fruition. So following the 2025 Interims, the headlines are revenue is growing, gross margins are improving, and adjusted EBITDA may have flipped positive. There is also a sizeable post-period contract that pays upfront – exactly what you want to see in a hardware-plus-SaaS business. Management says it is on track for at least 200% year-over-year growth in Lokies revenues. Hardware sales today plant the seeds for higher-margin software tomorrow, because each deployed device drives ongoing SaaS subscriptions and that change in mix is already visible with hopefully SaaS doing the heavy lifting on margins. Additional improvement in gross profit margins would be the tailwind towards profitability. The upfront payment on the Contguard contract is most welcome with some Revenue landing in 2025 and the majority in 2026 but that's excellent for cashflow and reduces execution risk. There are tighter protections for lenders and hitting those monthly payments is important. On the + side one of the loans is already being repaid in instalments. According to their cash flow forecasts Management believes that with the benefit of production efficiencies, customer purchase agreements and the loan extensions that  it can meet its obligations. However,  the two CLNs are convertible into up to 117.1 million shares as at 30 June 2025. That is a significant source of potential dilution if converted. In Ecuador,  integration has been completed and initial vehicles are connected. Management expects deployments to have increased in H2/25 whilst in Mexico,– roughly half of the contract has been executed, with the remainder currently on hold. No timeline disclosed. There are more products to broaden the addressable market and improve the SaaS opportunity whilst diversifying away from any single device line. Overall, the business is beginning to show signs of slowly moving in the right direction on sales, margins and profitability measures, albeit from a constrained balance sheet. If t42 converts its sales pipeline and keeps costs tight, the operational progress could start to outpace
