data.author: bunsenburner123
data.content: 🔥 TRAC is one of those rare AIM setups where the risk/reward is genuinely asymmetric. At a £1.5m market cap, you’re effectively buying a real, revenue-generating IoT business for less than the value of its tech, customer pipeline, and future optionality combined. This isn’t a concept stock anymore — it’s executing: •	Revenues growing fast •	EBITDA turning positive •	Costs under control •	Real customers, real hardware, real recurring income The kicker? The market is still pricing it like it’s broken. If even one of the following lands: •	a meaningful contract announcement •	a strategic partner or JV •	confirmation of sustained profitability •	or broader recognition of its container-tracking tech …the rerate could be violent. At £1.5m, this is the kind of setup where: •	2× feels reasonable •	3–5× is very possible •	and anything larger becomes plausible if momentum builds It’s exactly the sort of small-cap that quietly trades sideways… then suddenly reprices in days, not months. High risk? Yes. High conviction upside? Absolutely. This is the kind of stock that doesn’t reward hesitation — it rewards being early.

data.author: Nig1954
data.content: I'm not aware that any specified chartist has issued a prediction about the performance of t42 in 2026 as I haven't seen any widely publicised forecast by a major financial analyst or firm. There's a lot of speculative discussions on share forums which suggests that the general sentiment is positive and that 2026 could shape up to be a strong year due to business improvements and new contracts and that it appears to be getting its finances in order. However, technical analysts really struggle to accurately predict share price movements in AIM companies due to the specific structural characteristics of AIM. Many companies have low trading volumes making it extremely difficult to buy or sell large positions without significantly affecting the the price. Low liquidity means that price movements are often erratic driven by a few large trades or individual investors rather than broad market psychology. There is often less media and analysis coverage which means information isn't widely disseminated or "priced in" efficiently which leads to sudden news driven price swings that no chart pattern could predict. Share prices of small companies are usually linked to single significant events such as a major contract win which happen without warning and can cause huge one-off price movements that defy historical patterns. Prices are also more susceptible to manipulation and the lack of sufficient reliable  historical data means its almost impossible impossible to form robust technical analysis which weighs heavily on past price action. Strong fundamentals are what drives the price of companies similar to t42 and these focus on the intrinsic value, financial health and management quality of the underlying company. Management have been making a lot of optimistic noises since the rebranding but nothing fundamental will change until they announce a major breakthrough with an award winning contract gain which will significantly improve the company's finances. t42 doesn't hold surplus cash so its scope is limited unless it can draw upon support from other financial benefactors but this will come at a price, possibly share dilution, or some of the financial rewards being diverted elsewhere. Their products seem to be held in high regard and they  proved their resilience during the recent AWS outage when many of their competitors struggled. I like the architectural design of their products and clearly a lot of thought and careful long term planning has gone into this which means they're less prone to suffering from unforeseen events which cripple many of their close competitors. For the moment they haven't managed to break through the ceiling despite all of the optimism generated several years ago with talks of multi-million dollars contracts in LatAm. The fact they've managed to survive for so long in such a cut throat environment  is some form of testament to their resilience but all of that optimism needs to be turned into something more tangible.

data.author: Nig1954
data.content: We'll see what the AGM brings along in 2 days time. Personally I'm looking for some clarity and realism as it's been deafeningly quiet this year with no discernible indication of anymore contract wins other than Contguard. An up-to-date assessment of the contracts announced in 2023 and 2024 would be most welcome. I'm hoping that H2/25 performance will reflect that when the Y/E accounting position is revealed. An update would also be welcome in relation to the development of our revolutionary innovative new product solution for the refrigerated air cargo supply chain. Hopefully this will represent a paradigm shift for the air cargo industry providing unprecedented control, efficiency and profitability, as previously promised. Two and a half years and still waiting on that score. There were also those series of mysterious tweets back in April/ May 2025 which supposedly signalled some imminent good news which doesn't yet appear to have materialised. An indication of the progress would be appreciated. Finally  resilience of t42's products was proven in the recent AWS outage which apparently made the Industry sit up and take note. Are there any signs that this will translate into larger and more profitable contracts for the company.

Uri maintains it would take 2/3 years for a competitor to replicate because that capability is engineered into our platform and isn't something that could be done overnight. This forms part of the technological advantage our products have which in Management's view would take a third party 2/3 years to catch-up but in the meantime we may have moved further ahead. Some parties thought it was suggested we may get an update in early February. I wouldn't bet on that but would be extremely pleased if this comes to fruition. So following the 2025 Interims, the headlines are revenue is growing, gross margins are improving, and adjusted EBITDA may have flipped positive. There is also a sizeable post-period contract that pays upfront – exactly what you want to see in a hardware-plus-SaaS business. Management says it is on track for at least 200% year-over-year growth in Lokies revenues. Hardware sales today plant the seeds for higher-margin software tomorrow, because each deployed device drives ongoing SaaS subscriptions and that change in mix is already visible with hopefully SaaS doing the heavy lifting on margins. Additional improvement in gross profit margins would be the tailwind towards profitability. The upfront payment on the Contguard contract is most welcome with some Revenue landing in 2025 and the majority in 2026 but that's excellent for cashflow and reduces execution risk. There are tighter protections for lenders and hitting those monthly payments is important. On the + side one of the loans is already being repaid in instalments. According to their cash flow forecasts Management believes that with the benefit of production efficiencies, customer purchase agreements and the loan extensions that  it can meet its obligations. However,  the two CLNs are convertible into up to 117.1 million shares as at 30 June 2025. That is a significant source of potential dilution if converted. In Ecuador,  integration has been completed and initial vehicles are connected. Management expects deployments to have increased in H2/25 whilst in Mexico,– roughly half of the contract has been executed, with the remainder currently on hold. No timeline disclosed. There are more products to broaden the addressable market and improve the SaaS opportunity whilst diversifying away from any single device line. Overall, the business is beginning to show signs of slowly moving in the right direction on sales, margins and profitability measures, albeit from a constrained balance sheet. If t42 converts its sales pipeline and keeps costs tight, the operational progress could start to outpace

data.author: OLTB

data.author: LTbeliever
data.content: That's about 10.000 extra annually, over annual expenses of 2.5mln; I see your point OLTB but who else would lend the Co, 250k on a long-term, unsecured basis?  And at what rate? We pay 20-25%pa on credit card debt, for example. Although I am biased, IMO the silver lining is the signaling to the Mkt that the Co will afford - in 2026 - to pay more as interest to its CTO and that it's slowly getting its debts in order (including the extra shares=dilution, in lieu of the Directors' fees). We will see what happens when these extra shares hit the market tomorrow AM.
